items.significance: Anant Chaturdashi vrat for unending prosperity using Anant sutra (thread); also last day of public Ganesh festival with Visarjan.
items.katha: Story: Brahmin Kaudinya lost wealth after discarding Anant thread; after realizing mistake, he resumed vrat and regained fortune.
items.morning: Morning snan; draw Anant symbol (14 knots thread); Ganesha still installed.
items.daytime: Vrat with light food; Anant katha reading; tie Anant sutra on arm.
items.mainpuja: Afternoon Vishnu Anant puja, then Ganesh Visarjan procession: final aarti, immersion in water body with prayers.
items.fastingrules: Those fasting break after Anant puja and Visarjan with feast.
items.daan: Food, clothes, sweets, threads to poor, children.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ अनन्ताय नमः” 108 times; Ganesha mantra as Visarjan ends.

items.significance: Full Moon for charity, Satyanarayan vrat, and transition towards Ashwin and Navratri energies.
items.katha: Many Satyanarayan and community kirtans done; considered auspicious close of bhadrapada’s bright half.
items.morning: Early snan; sankalpa for Purnima vrat.
items.daytime: Partial fast or one‑meal satvik; Vishnu japa, reading.
items.mainpuja: Evening Satyanarayan puja and katha; aarti; prasad.
items.fastingrules: Fast broken after puja/prasad (or moonrise if following that rule).
items.daan: Food, grains, clothes; annadan.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ नारायणाय नमः” 108 times.

items.englishname: Vishwakarma Puja (industry date; some regions on 17/18/20 depending solar transit)
items.tithimonth: Solar transit in Virgo / industrial date panchang​
items.significance: Worship of divine architect, patron of artisans/engineers; tools and machines are blessed.
items.katha: Vishwakarma seen as craftsman of gods’ weapons and palaces; this day workers thank him and pray for safety.
items.morning: Morning snan; decorate workplace; set Vishwakarma image at shop/factory.
items.daytime: Tool/vehicle puja: incense, flowers, kumkum; no machine work during puja time.
items.mainpuja: Aarti and prasad distribution at workplace.
items.fastingrules: No fast; focus on safety and gratitude.
items.daan: Food, sweets to workers; safety equipment donation.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ विश्वकर्मणे नमः” 108 times.

items.significance: Wednesday Pradosh especially good for intellect, business, communication.
items.katha: Pradosh vrat plus Budha’s influence helps with clarity and good speech.
items.morning: Morning snan; Shiva sthapana; sankalpa.
items.daytime: Light fast, japa “Om Namah Shivaya;” check/plan finances, communication.
items.mainpuja: Pradosh abhishek, bilva, incense; Mahamrityunjaya; aarti.
items.fastingrules: Fast ends after puja.
items.daan: Food, books, pens to students; ghee, bel to temple.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” & “ॐ बुं बुधाय नमः” 108 each.

items.englishname: (Alt date) Ganesh Visarjan / Anant Chaturdashi (per DrikPanchang for some states)
items.significance: Some regions immerse Ganesha today; treat as alternate if you followed 16 Sep for New Delhi.
items.katha: Same Anant/Visarjan themes.
items.morning: As above.
items.daytime: As above.
items.mainpuja: As above.
items.fastingrules: As above.
items.daan: Note in Excel which date you adopt; other as “alt date”.
items.notes: Mantra: same as Anant/Visarjan row.

items.significance: Ekadashi specially for liberation of ancestors during Pitru Paksha; grants Pitru‑moksha and removes Pitru dosha.
items.katha: Katha: King Indrasena rescued father from Yama‑loka by keeping this Ekadashi and donating its punya to him.
items.morning: Early snan; tarpan for Pitru; then Vishnu image; Ekadashi sankalpa.
items.daytime: No grains; fruits/milk; Vishnu Sahasranama, Indira katha; remember ancestors with gratitude.
items.mainpuja: Evening Vishnu puja; aarti; mental offering of punya to Pitru.
items.fastingrules: Parana on Dwadashi after tarpan/Vishnu puja; offer some food in names of ancestors.
items.daan: Food, grains, sesame, clothes to poor/Brahmins in name of Pitru.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” and “ॐ पितृभ्यः स्वधा नमः” 108 each.

items.significance: Evening Shiva fast for cleansing, peace, and health within Pitru Paksha.
items.katha: Same Pradosh legends; occurring in Pitru Paksha supports karmic cleaning.
items.morning: Morning snan; Pradosh sankalpa.
items.daytime: Phalahar fast; Shiva nama‑japa.
items.mainpuja: Pradosh abhishek with water/milk, bilva; Mahamrityunjaya; aarti.
items.fastingrules: Fast ends after puja.
items.daan: Milk, rice, ghee; food to poor/sadhus.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108+ times.

items.muhurat: Snan‑daan, Pitru tarpan in morning panchang+1
items.significance: Key Amavasya for ancestors; marks start of Pitru Paksha; crucial for tarpan, shraddha, and remembering lineage.
items.katha: Bhishma and other texts stress Pitru Paksha offerings; Mahalaya songs and stories in Bengal recall Goddess and Pitru blessings.
items.morning: Very early snan; preferably river or at least Ganga jal bath; prepare tarpan items.
items.daytime: Perform elaborate tarpan/shraddha with priest if possible; keep mind deeply respectful; maintain satvik diet and thoughts.
items.mainpuja: Evening deepa, Narayana/Devi puja, minimal celebration; listen to Mahalaya‑type stotras if desired.
items.fastingrules: Some keep fast or one‑meal satvik food; avoid non‑veg, alcohol, loud entertainment.
items.daan: Sesame, food, clothes to poor; feeding cows, crows, dogs as symbolic Pitru offerings.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ पितृभ्यः स्वधा नमः” repeatedly during tarpan; “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108 times.

items.significance: Start of 9‑day Sharad Navratri for Durga’s nine forms; very important for sadhana and house/inner cleansing.
items.katha: Legends of Devi slaying Mahishasura and other demons; each day a different form is worshipped, culminating in Vijayadashami.
items.morning: Early snan; clean puja area; perform Ghatasthapana (kalash with mango leaves and coconut, Durga image); take 9‑day vrat sankalpa.
items.daytime: Partial fast (one meal or fruits), daily reading of Durga Saptashati/Devi Kavach, japa “Ya Devi Sarvabhuteshu…”.
items.mainpuja: Evening aarti and bhajans; light lamp near kalash; simple naivedya.
items.fastingrules: Fast pattern continues daily till Ashtami/Navami; many avoid onion/garlic throughout.
items.daan: Food, fruits, clothes to Kanya girls, poor women.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ दुं दुर्गायै नमः” 108 times daily.

items.significance: Day 2 honors Brahmacharini, giver of tapas‑shakti and steadiness in sadhana.
items.katha: She performed severe austerities to obtain Shiva as husband; symbolizes perseverance and simplicity.
items.morning: Snan; worship Brahmacharini with white flowers; offer sugar.
items.daytime: Continue fast (fruits/one‑meal); chant her name and read short katha.
items.mainpuja: Evening aarti, bhajans.
items.fastingrules: Same Navratri vrat rules.
items.daan: Sugar, white clothes, food to students/sadhaks.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ देवी ब्रह्मचारिण्यै नमः” 108 times.

items.significance: Day 3: Chandraghanta, symbol of courage and removal of fear.
items.katha: She bears crescent moon on forehead; rides lion; destroys enemies of dharma.
items.morning: Snan; worship with fragrant flowers; ring bell gently during aarti.
items.daytime: Fast continues; read small katha; focus on fearlessness.
items.mainpuja: Evening puja and aarti.
items.fastingrules: As per Navratri vrata.
items.daan: Food, support to women facing abuse/fear.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ देवी चन्द्रघंटायै नमः” 108 times.

items.significance: Day 4: Kushmanda who creates the universe; first visible Chandra of bright fortnight.
items.katha: Universe created from her cosmic smile; associated with health and vitality.
items.morning: Snan; Kushmanda puja, offer white pumpkin or malpua if possible.
items.daytime: Fasting pattern continues; japa; seva.
items.mainpuja: After sunset, Chandra Darshan: offer arghya, short Moon mantra; then aarti.
items.fastingrules: Continue Navratri fast; no separate Chandra fast.
items.daan: Rice, sweets, buttermilk to poor.
items.notes: Mantra: Kushmanda – “ॐ देवी कूष्मांडायै नमः” 108; Chandra – “ॐ चन्द्राय नमः” 11.

items.significance: Day 5: Skandamata, mother of Kartikeya; grants children’s welfare and bhakti.
items.katha: She carries child Skanda on lap; worship brings motherly protection.
items.morning: Snan; Skandamata puja; offer bananas.
items.daytime: Fast and japa as usual; focus on children’s well‑being.
items.mainpuja: Evening aarti and bhajans.
items.fastingrules: Navratri fast as per pattern.
items.daan: Fruits, clothes, food to children.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ देवी स्कन्दमातायै नमः” 108.

items.significance: Day 6: Katyayani, powerful for marriage, removal of delayed marriage doshas.
items.katha: Gopis worshipped her to obtain Krishna; known as fierce warrior form.
items.morning: Snan; yellow clothes; puja with turmeric, yellow flowers.
items.daytime: Fast; read Katyayani katha; pray for right spouse/relationship harmony.
items.mainpuja: Evening aarti.
items.fastingrules: As per Navratri vrata.
items.daan: Food, haldi, bangles to girls/women.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ देवी कात्यायन्यै नमः” 108.

items.significance: Day 7: Kalaratri, destroyer of intense negativity, fear, black magic.
items.katha: She removed demons like Shumbha–Nishumbha’s hordes; fierce yet protective.
items.morning: Snan; red/black flowers; simple puja with deepa.
items.daytime: Fast; meditate on letting go of deep fears & vices.
items.mainpuja: Evening aarti; more japa than decoration.
items.fastingrules: Vrat pattern same.
items.daan: Food, lamps to poor homes/temples.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ देवी कालरात्र्यै नमः” 108.

items.significance: Major day of Navratri: Mahagauri, Kanya pujan, and often havan; very powerful for shuddhi and wish‑fulfilment.
items.katha: Mahagauri regained pure fair form after tapas and Shiva’s grace; Kanya seen as living Devi.
items.morning: Snan; special Durga/ Mahagauri puja; arrange Kanya pujan (9 girls + 1 boy as Bhairav ideally).
items.daytime: Fast till Kanya pujan; read Durga Saptashati finale; homa if possible.
items.mainpuja: Kanya pujan: wash feet, tilak, feed, give gifts; aarti of Durga; bhajans.
items.fastingrules: Many end Navratri fast here; break after Kanya pujan with prasad and satvik food.
items.daan: Food, clothes, bangles to Kanya; dakshina to priests.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ देवी महागौर्यै नमः” 108.

items.significance: Final day of Navratri: Siddhidatri, granter of siddhis; also used as alternate Kanya‑pujan day.
items.katha: She grants eight siddhis to devas and devotees; symbol of completeness.
items.morning: Snan; Navami puja; optionally do Kanya pujan if not done on Ashtami.
items.daytime: Complete Durga Saptashati; perform small homa.
items.mainpuja: Final Navratri aarti; distribute prasad.
items.fastingrules: For those ending fast on Navami, Parana after puja/ Kanya feeding.
items.daan: Food, clothes, annadan at temples.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ देवी सिद्धिदात्र्यै नमः” 108.

items.significance: Celebrates victory of good over evil – Rama’s victory over Ravana, Devi’s victory over Mahishasura; auspicious for new ventures, vidyarambha, shastra puja.
items.katha: Ramayana war ends on this day; many also burn Ravana effigies; Ayudha puja marks tools/weapons worship.
items.morning: Morning snan; simple home puja to Durga/Rama.
items.daytime: Visit temple; worship tools, vehicles (Ayudha puja); children start new books/music etc.
items.mainpuja: Evening Ramlila/ Dussehra witnessing; aarti at home; small Shami‑tree puja where followed.
items.fastingrules: No fast; feast but keep sattvik; ideal day to start new study/work.
items.daan: Food, books, instruments to students; charity.
items.notes: Mantra: “श्री राम जय राम जय जय राम” 108; or “ॐ दुं दुर्गायै नमः”.

items.significance: Ekadashi for destroying sins (paap) and getting Vaikuntha‑gati; very praised in Puranas.
items.katha: Katha of hunter/king freed from heavy sins by this Ekadashi and Vishnu worship; even hearing its greatness gives merit.
items.morning: Early snan; Vishnu image; sankalpa for vrat.
items.daytime: No grains; fruits/milk fast; Vishnu Sahasranama, Papankusha katha; avoid harshness, lies.
items.mainpuja: Evening Vishnu/Satyanarayan puja; aarti, bhajans.
items.fastingrules: Parana on Dwadashi with tulsi‑water and light food.
items.daan: Food, grains, sesame, clothes to poor/Brahmins.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108/1008 times.

items.significance: Pradosh fast for overall forgiveness, peace, and prosperity.
items.katha: Devas’ troubles were removed during Pradosh by Shiva’s Tandava; hence this twilight is sacred.
items.morning: Morning snan; Shiva sthapana; sankalpa.
items.daytime: Fruit/milk fast; “Om Namah Shivaya” japa; avoid rajasic behaviour.
items.mainpuja: Pradosh puja: abhishek, bilva‑archana, incense, lamp; Mahamrityunjaya japa; aarti.
items.fastingrules: Fast ends after puja with satvik meal.
items.daan: Milk, rice, sweets; bel leaves and ghee to temple.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” and “ॐ त्र्यम्बकं यजामहे…” 108 each.

items.significance: Night of brightest full moon, believed that Lakshmi roams asking “Ko‑jaagarti?” (who is awake); special kheer exposed to moonlight is taken as medicine‑like prasad.
items.katha: Legends link it to Lakshmi’s blessing of wakeful devotees, and Krishna’s Rasa‑lila with Gopis under Sharad moon.
items.morning: Early snan; brief Lakshmi puja; arrange for night vigil.
items.daytime: Light daytime food or partial fast; prepare thick kheer in evening.
items.mainpuja: After moonrise, Lakshmi puja, aarti; keep kheer in moonlight; consume later night/next morning as prasad.
items.fastingrules: Some do night‑long jagran; fast may be fruits/one‑meal; break after night puja or next morning.
items.daan: Food, sweets, clothes to poor, especially women.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ श्रीं महालक्ष्म्यै नमः” 108 times; also do some “श्री सूक्त” recitation.

items.significance: North Indian married women’s fast for husband’s long life, marital harmony.
items.katha: Legend of Veeravati and other queens who regained husbands by steadfast Karwa fast.
items.morning: Before sunrise (sargi), eat from mother‑in‑law; then snan; adorn in bridal‑like clothes; vow nirjal fast.
items.daytime: Vrat katha reading in afternoon; mehendi, songs; maintain nirjal upvas.
items.mainpuja: Evening Gauri/Chauth Mata puja; after Moonrise, view Moon through sieve, then husband’s face; water offered; fast broken.
items.fastingrules: Strict nirjal from pre‑dawn till post‑Moonrise; then full meal.
items.daan: Food, clothes, cosmetics to married women and poor girls.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ गौरी नमः” 108; simple “सातों जन्म तुम्हारा सुहाग रहे” sankalpically.

items.significance: Mothers fast for well‑being and long life of children.
items.katha: Ahoi Mata once accidentally harmed baby animal; by vrat she atoned and her children prospered.
items.morning: Morning snan; mothers draw/keep Ahoi image; sankalpa for fast.
items.daytime: Nirjal or fruits‑only; day spent in sewa and katha listening.
items.mainpuja: At starsight, offer water & prasad to Ahoi Mata; aarti; then see stars with thread‑count; break fast.
items.fastingrules: Fast from sunrise till starsight; then satvik meal.
items.daan: Food, clothes to children; charity in name of kids.
items.notes: Mantra: simple “अहोई माता” prayer; “ॐ अहोई मातायै नमः” 108.

items.significance: Ekadashi for peace, prosperity, and gradual liberation; named for Rama.
items.katha: Katha of once‑sinful persons redeemed by this fast and Rama‑nama; emphasises truth, non‑violence along with fast.
items.morning: Morning snan; Vishnu/Rama image; Ekadashi sankalpa.
items.daytime: No grains; fruits/milk; Ramayana reading and Rama‑nama japa.
items.mainpuja: Evening Vishnu–Rama puja; aarti; bhajans.
items.fastingrules: Dwadashi Parana with tulsi‑water and light food.
items.daan: Food, blankets, grains; donations for Ramayana pravachan.
items.notes: Mantra: “श्री राम जय राम जय जय राम” 108/1008 times.

items.englishname: Dhanteras / Dhantrayodashi (per some lists, alt: 26 Oct)
items.significance: First day of Diwali cluster; buying utensils/gold; also Dhanvantari Jayanti for health.
items.katha: Dhanvantari emerged with Amrita from Samudra‑manthan; house lit to invite Lakshmi.
items.morning: Morning snan; home/business cleaning.
items.daytime: Auspicious buying of metal, gold, utensils (within reason); prep for puja.
items.mainpuja: Evening Lakshmi‑Kuber–Dhanvantari puja; rows of diyas at door/windows.
items.fastingrules: No fast; focus on satvik feast and puja.
items.daan: Food, medicines, money to sick/hospitals; grains to poor.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ श्रीं महालक्ष्म्यै नमः” and “ॐ श्रीं क्लीं महामायै नमः” 108; for health “ॐ नमो धन्वन्तरये नमः”.

items.englishname: Labh Panchami (regional; last Diwali business day)
items.significance: In Gujarat and business communities, marks final Diwali day; auspicious to start books/ledgers and business ventures.
items.katha: Traders reopen account books after Diwali, invoking Ganesha–Lakshmi for profit (labh) and good customers.
items.morning: Snan; small puja at home or shop.
items.daytime: Clean shop/office; decorate with rangoli and flowers; write “Shubh Labh” on ledgers.
items.mainpuja: Short Lakshmi–Ganesha puja at workplace; aarti; prasad.
items.fastingrules: No vrat; only auspicious business start.
items.daan: Sweets, food to staff; charity as per ability.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ श्रीं महालक्ष्म्यै नमः” 108 times.

items.significance: Marks waking of Vishnu after 4‑month Chaturmas; marriages and big functions restart.
items.katha: Lakshmi asked Vishnu to rest; from Devshayani to this day he sleeps; waking symbolises fresh auspicious period.
items.morning: Early snan; Vishnu image; Ekadashi sankalpa.
items.daytime: No grains; fruits/milk fast; chanting Vishnu Sahasranama, Dev Uthani katha; many do tulsi‑parikrama.
items.mainpuja: Evening Vishnu/Hari‑Lakshmi puja; aarti; pushpanjali; some perform symbolic Tulsi–Shaligram marriage.
items.fastingrules: Parana on Dwadashi with tulsi‑water and satvik food.
items.daan: Food, grains, clothes; donations to temples/ashrams.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108/1008 times.

items.significance: Ceremonial marriage of Tulsi with Vishnu/Shaligram, symbolising end of Chaturmas and start of wedding season.
items.katha: Tulsi once Vrinda, wife of Jalandhar; after events, became sacred plant; Vishnu promised to wed her.
items.morning: Morning snan; decorate Tulsi pot as bride; arrange small Shaligram/ Vishnu as groom.
items.daytime: Prepare mandap, light decorations, sweets; invite family.
items.mainpuja: Evening Tulsi Vivah: kanyadaan, mangalsutra/cloth tying between Tulsi & Shaligram, mantra, aarti, kirtan.
items.fastingrules: No strict fast; some maintain light satvik food till evening puja.
items.daan: Food, clothes, sweets to Brahmins and poor couples.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ तुलस्यै नमः” and “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108 each.

items.significance: First Diwali day: buying utensils/gold, lighting lamps; also Dhanvantari Jayanti for health.
items.katha: Dhanvantari emerged with Amrita pot at Samudra‑manthan; families light lamps to invite wealth and good health.
items.morning: Morning snan; clean and decorate home/shop.
items.daytime: Purchase metal/utensils/gold within capacity; prepare for evening diya‑lighting.
items.mainpuja: Evening Lakshmi‑Kuber–Dhanvantari puja; light rows of diyas at doors and windows; aarti.
items.fastingrules: No vrat; feast with satvik items.
items.daan: Food, medicines, money to hospitals/poor; oil, lamps for temples.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ श्रीं महालक्ष्म्यै नमः” and “ॐ नमो धन्वन्तरये नमः” 108 each.

items.englishname: Naraka Chaturdashi (Choti Diwali) & Lakshmi Puja / Diwali; Narak Nivaran Chaturdashi; Kedar Gauri Vrat
items.muhurat: Abhyang snan at Brahma‑muhurta; Lakshmi Puja in Pradosh Kaal bookmypoojaonline+1
items.focus: Lakshmi, Ganesha, Naraka‑asur story, Kedar Gauri
items.significance: Main Diwali night: Lakshmi–Ganesh puja for wealth and auspiciousness; Naraka Chaturdashi bath for sin‑removal.
items.katha: Krishna killed Narakasura this tithi and freed 16,000 women; Lakshmi roams to bless clean, lit houses.
items.morning: Pre‑dawn oil/ubtan bath (Abhyang snan); wear new/clean clothes.
items.daytime: Clean house; decorate with rangoli, lamps; prepare sweets & savouries; avoid anger/quarrels.
items.mainpuja: In Pradosh (after sunset, before ~9 PM), main Lakshmi–Ganesh puja: kalash, coins, sweets, Lakshmi aarti, Ganesha Atharvashirsha; then diyas, crackers (moderate).
items.fastingrules: No fast; day of feasting; some keep light until Lakshmi puja done.
items.daan: Food, clothes, sweets to poor; donations to workers/house‑helps.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ श्रीं महालक्ष्म्यै नमः” 108; “ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108.

items.significance: Celebrates Krishna lifting Govardhan hill to protect Vrindavan; also Bali Pratipada–honouring King Bali.
items.katha: Krishna urged villagers to worship Govardhan instead of Indra; he then lifted hill for 7 days.
items.morning: Morning snan; draw/ mound Govardhan (cow‑dung hill or rangoli).
items.daytime: Prepare many bhog items (Annakut); decorate cows if possible.
items.mainpuja: Govardhan puja: circumambulate mound, offer food, kirtan “Govardhan Giridhari”; feast with family.
items.fastingrules: No vrat; festival feast day.
items.daan: Food, fodder for cows; annadan at temples.
items.notes: Mantra: “गोवर्धनधारी गोपाल कृष्ण की जय” or “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108 times.

items.significance: Sisters pray for brothers’ long life and well‑being, similar to Raksha Bandhan but post‑Diwali.
items.katha: Yamuna welcomed brother Yama, applied tilak and fed him; he granted boon that sisters doing similar will bless brothers.
items.morning: Morning snan; sisters prepare thali.
items.daytime: Brothers visit sisters’ homes.
items.mainpuja: Tilak, aarti of brother, sweet feeding; brother gives gifts; simple family meal.
items.fastingrules: No fast; only simple auspicious conduct.
items.daan: Gifts, food, clothes to sisters; charity in siblings’ names.
items.notes: Mantra: simple sankalp‑prayer; “ॐ यमाय नमः” (for protection) few times.

items.muhurat: Snan‑daan at sunrise; deepdaan at night panchang+1
items.significance: Dev Diwali: devas celebrate Diwali on Kartik Purnima; extremely sacred for Ganga snan, charity, lamps on ghats.
items.katha: Legends: Tripurasura slain by Shiva on this day (Tripurari Purnima); Vishnu took Matsya avatar; many tirthas considered especially powerful.
items.morning: Early snan (river or Ganga jal); take vow for charity and lamps.
items.daytime: Maintain satvik food; visit temple/tirtha; annadan.
items.mainpuja: Night: light rows of lamps at home/riverbank; Vishnu–Shiva–Ganga puja; Satyanarayan katha optional.
items.fastingrules: Some keep partial fast; break after night puja or next morning.
items.daan: Food, clothes, lamps, grains to poor and at ghats.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” and “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108 each.

items.significance: Start of very sacred month, good for Krishna and Lakshmi worship, especially on Thursdays.
items.katha: Krishna in Gita calls Margashirsha his own month; associated with devotion and prosperity.
items.morning: Snan; simple puja to Krishna/Lakshmi.
items.daytime: Decide extra sadhana: e.g. Margashirsha Thursdays puja, japa.
items.mainpuja: Evening diya and aarti.
items.fastingrules: No special fast; monthly discipline focus.
items.daan: Food/coins to poor as month‑start daan.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108 at month start.

items.significance: Monthly Sankashti fast for removal of obstacles, illness, financial issues.
items.katha: Typical katha: a family/king saved from disaster by this vrat and hearing the story; Ganesha promises to remove “sankat”.
items.morning: Pre‑dawn snan; establish Ganesha; fast sankalpa.
items.daytime: Nirjal/fruit fast; Ganesh japa; read or hear Sankashti katha.
items.mainpuja: Evening puja, abhishek, durva, modak; katha; aarti; Moon darshan and arghya.
items.fastingrules: Fast ends only after Moon sight and offering to Moon & Ganesha; then prasad and light meal.
items.daan: Modak, laddoo, books for children.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108/1008 times.

items.significance: Ekadashi commemorating birth of Ekadashi Devi; best for conquering negative energies and tamasic tendencies.
items.katha: Vishnu created Ekadashi Devi from his energy to defeat demon Murasura; those who fast gain protection.
items.morning: Morning snan; Vishnu image; Ekadashi sankalpa.
items.daytime: No grains; fruits/milk; read Utpanna Ekadashi katha and Sahasranama; avoid lethargy.
items.mainpuja: Evening Vishnu puja, aarti, bhajans.
items.fastingrules: Parana on Dwadashi after sunrise with tulsi‑water then light food.
items.daan: Food, grains, blankets to poor.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108/1008.

items.significance: Evening fast for forgiveness, inner peace, health.
items.katha: Pradosh legends: Shiva’s dance at this time freed devas from suffering.
items.morning: Morning snan; vow for Pradosh fast; Shivalinga set.
items.daytime: Fruit/milk fast; “Om Namah Shivaya” japa; read Shiva katha.
items.mainpuja: Pradosh Kaal abhishek, bilva‑archana, incense, deep; Mahamrityunjaya japa; aarti.
items.fastingrules: Fast ends after puja with satvik meal.
items.daan: Milk, rice, white sweets; bel leaves to temple.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” & “ॐ त्र्यम्बकं यजामहे…” 108 each.

items.significance: Monthly Shivratri, very strong with cool season starting; good for deep japa and meditation.
items.katha: Same jyotirlinga pillar‑of‑light story; emphasises transcending mind.
items.morning: Snan; fast decision; Shivalinga.
items.daytime: Upvas; japa, parayan of Shiva stotra.
items.mainpuja: Four‑prahar night‑puja if possible, with repeated abhishek, bilva, aarti.
items.fastingrules: Parana next morning after dawn Shiva & Surya puja.
items.daan: Food, water, woollens to poor.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” many malas; Mahamrityunjaya 108.

items.muhurat: Snan‑daan; Pitru tarpan in morning panchang​
items.significance: New moon for ancestor offerings and charity before new lunar month.
items.katha: Standard Amavasya shraddha texts emphasise peace for Pitru and removal of doshas.
items.morning: Early snan; set tarpan materials (water, sesame).
items.daytime: Perform tarpan/shraddha (with priest or simple mantras); keep sattvik.
items.mainpuja: Evening diya, Narayana aarti.
items.fastingrules: Some keep one‑meal or fruit fast; break after daan.
items.daan: Food, sesame, clothes to poor/Brahmins in ancestor names.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ पितृभ्यः स्वधा नमः” 108; “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108.

items.muhurat: Just after sunset, first moon sight panchang​
items.significance: First waxing Moon brings mental peace and emotional balance.
items.katha: Story of Chandra’s curse and refuge with Shiva; honouring Moon calms mind.
items.morning: Normal snan; prepare plate with rice, sweets, water.
items.daytime: Maintain gentle, sattvik mood.
items.mainpuja: At first sight of Moon, offer arghya with water/rice; chant Chandra mantra; aarti.
items.fastingrules: No fast; some break voluntary upvas after Chandra Darshan.
items.daan: Rice, milk sweets to children/poor.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ चन्द्राय नमः” 11–27 times.

items.significance: Monthly Vinayaka Chaturthi for success, wisdom, and removal of obstacles in new bright fortnight.
items.katha: Similar to other Chaturthis; many do day‑fast and evening Ganesha puja.
items.morning: Morning snan; Ganesha sthapana; sankalpa.
items.daytime: Fruit fast; japa of “Om Gam Ganapataye Namah”; read Ganesha katha.
items.mainpuja: Evening abhishek, durva, sweets; aarti.
items.fastingrules: Fast ends after evening puja.
items.daan: Modak, laddoo, books to students.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108/1008.

items.significance: Very important in South (especially Tamil Nadu) for victory, protection, overcoming enemies.
items.katha: Remembers Skanda’s victory over Surapadma; devotees do fast, kavacham recitation, visit Murugan temples.
items.morning: Morning snan; Murugan image/Vel.
items.daytime: Upvas on fruits/milk; recite Skanda Shashti Kavacham; visit temple if possible.
items.mainpuja: Evening aarti, coconut/banana offerings.
items.fastingrules: Fast broken after puja with satvik food.
items.daan: Food, sweets, gifts to boys/students.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ सरवनभवाय नमः” 108.

items.significance: Monthly Ashtami fast for protection and shakti.
items.katha: Devi promises to destroy inner and outer enemies of devotees remembering her on Ashtami.
items.morning: Snan; Durga image; sankalpa.
items.daytime: Fruit/one‑meal fast; “Ya Devi Sarvabhuteshu” recitation; small Saptashati path if possible.
items.mainpuja: Evening puja, kumkum, flowers, kheer/fruit naivedya; aarti.
items.fastingrules: Fast broken after evening puja with prasad and food.
items.daan: Food, fruits, clothes to women/girls.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ दुं दुर्गायै नमः” 108.

items.significance: Akshay Navami believed to grant inexhaustible punya and prosperity; Jagaddhatri Puja (esp. Bengal) celebrates Devi as supporter of universe.
items.katha: Legends link day to the start of Satya Yuga farming and also to Krishnavatar’s pastimes; Jagaddhatri icon shows Devi subduing egoic lion.
items.morning: Morning snan; simple Vishnu or Devi puja.
items.daytime: Optional fast or simple satvik one‑meal; japa; charity.
items.mainpuja: Evening Jagaddhatri puja where celebrated: elaborate aarti, lamps, bhajans.
items.fastingrules: No strict rules; vrat can be moderate as per strength.
items.daan: Food, grains, clothes; lamps.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” or “ॐ जगद्धात्र्यै नमः” 108.

items.englishname: (Regional) Jagaddhatri Puja Continues / Margashirsha Somvar Begins
items.significance: In some places Jagaddhatri continues; Margashirsha Mondays are good for Shiva/ Krishna upasana.
items.katha: Gita verse “māsānām mārgaśīrṣo ’ham” encourages enhanced sadhana in this month; Monday fasts popular.
items.morning: Snan; Shiva and/or Krishna puja.
items.daytime: Optional Somvar fast; japa; study of Gita.
items.mainpuja: Evening aarti; personal sankalpa for all Margashirsha Mondays.
items.fastingrules: If fasting, break after evening puja.
items.daan: Food, books, clothes to poor/students.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108; “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108.

items.significance: Ekadashi when Ekadashi Devi was “born” from Vishnu’s shakti; powerful to conquer tamas and strong negative impulses.
items.katha: Vishnu manifested Ekadashi Devi to slay demon Mura; observing this fast is said to destroy heavy sins and grant protection.
items.morning: Early snan; Vishnu murti; Ekadashi sankalpa.
items.daytime: No grains; fruits/milk; read Utpanna Ekadashi katha and Sahasranama; maintain sattva.
items.mainpuja: Evening Vishnu/Satyanarayan puja; aarti; bhajans.
items.fastingrules: Parana on Dwadashi with tulsi‑water first, then light satvik food.
items.daan: Food, grains, blankets to poor.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108/1008 times.

items.muhurat: Pradosh Kaal (~5:45–8:10 PM); night Nishita drikpanchang​
items.significance: Combination of Saturday Pradosh (Shani Pradosh) and monthly Shivaratri; good for Shani dosha, karmic cleansing, and deep Shiva bhakti.
items.katha: Stories tell of prisoners and debtors freed after Shani Pradosh vrat; Shivaratri recalls Shiva’s jyotirlinga form beyond time.
items.morning: Morning snan; Shivalinga sthapana; sankalpa for fast.
items.daytime: Upvas on fruits/milk; “Om Namah Shivaya” japa; Shani stotra (if needed).
items.mainpuja: Pradosh: abhishek, bilva, Mahamrityunjaya; later night: 2–4 pra­har Shivaratri puja, more abhishek and japa.
items.fastingrules: Fast typically from sunrise till next morning after dawn Shiva puja and Surya arghya.
items.daan: Food, black sesame, blankets, shoes to poor; oil & lamps to Shani/ Shiva temples.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” many malas; “ॐ शं शनैश्चराय नमः” 108.

items.significance: In some Shakta traditions, celebrates Devi in child form, symbolising innocence and pure shakti.
items.katha: Bala Tripurasundari appears as young girl who is nevertheless supreme Shakti, granting siddhi and protection.
items.morning: Snan; set small Devi‑as‑balika image; simple puja.
items.daytime: Gentle japa, reading Devi stotras; keep sattvik mood.
items.mainpuja: Aarti, offering of sweets, fruits.
items.fastingrules: No strict fast; optional light diet.
items.daan: Sweets, clothes to girl children.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ ऐं बालिकायै नमः” or “ॐ श्रीं ह्रीं क्लीं त्रिपुर sundaryai नमः” 108.

items.significance: New moon for shraddha/tarpan and charity, with cool season aiding seva.
items.katha: As with other Amavasyas, Pitru are believed to receive offerings and bless descendants.
items.morning: Early snan (river or with Ganga jal); prepare tarpan plate.
items.daytime: Perform tarpan/shraddha; maintain sattvik diet, calm speech.
items.mainpuja: Evening diya, Narayana/Kul‑devata aarti.
items.fastingrules: Many keep one‑meal satvik or fruit fast; break after daan/puja.
items.daan: Food, sesame, clothes, blankets to poor & Brahmins.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ पितृभ्यः स्वधा नमः” and “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108 each.

items.muhurat: Just after sunset, first moon sight drikpanchang​
items.significance: First waxing Moon after Amavasya; promotes mental peace and emotional balance.
items.katha: Chandra, once cursed, found refuge with Shiva; honouring him balances mind.
items.morning: Normal snan; ready plate with rice, sweets, water.
items.daytime: Maintain peaceful, sattvik thoughts.
items.mainpuja: At first sight of Moon, offer arghya with water/rice; chant Chandra mantra; aarti.
items.fastingrules: No fast; some break optional upvas after Moon sight.
items.daan: Rice and milk sweets to children/poor.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ चन्द्राय नमः” 11–27 times.

items.significance: Celebrates divine marriage of Rama–Sita; auspicious for marriages and grihastha dharma.
items.katha: Ramayana describes Janakpur wedding on this tithi; devotees recall ideal couple virtues.
items.morning: Snan; place Ram–Sita images; decorate as wedding scene.
items.daytime: Simple fast or satvik one‑meal; read Ramayana wedding chapter; teach children.
items.mainpuja: In temple/home, enact symbolic kalyanam; aarti; distribute prasad.
items.fastingrules: No strict fast; optional upvas ends after puja.
items.daan: Food, clothes to couples, assistance for poor weddings.
items.notes: Mantra: “श्री राम जय राम जय जय राम” 108; “सीताराम” japa.

items.significance: Observed especially in South/West as victory and protection vrat, and regional Champa Shashti for Shiva/Devi.
items.katha: Skanda’s battles and victory over Surapadma are remembered; Champa Shashti has local myths of demons slain.
items.morning: Morning snan; Murugan image/Vel, or regional deity.
items.daytime: Upvas on fruits/milk; recite Skanda Shashti Kavacham or local stotras.
items.mainpuja: Evening aarti, coconut, banana offerings.
items.fastingrules: Fast broken after puja with satvik meal.
items.daan: Food, sweets, gifts to boys and students.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ सरवनभवाय नमः” 108 times.

items.significance: Sun’s transit into Dhanu rashi; good for charity, pilgrimage planning, spiritual focus.
items.katha: Dhanu is linked to dharma, higher learning, pilgrimage; Surya’s entry supports such pursuits.
items.morning: Snan; offer arghya to Sun with Surya mantra.
items.daytime: Reflect on dharmic goals; plan tirtha/snana, donations.
items.mainpuja: Evening diya; brief Surya aarti.
items.fastingrules: No fast required; optional light satvik diet.
items.daan: Food, ghee, grains; support to students/spiritual centres.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ घृणि सू्र्याय नमः” 108.

items.significance: Monthly Ashtami fast for protection, shakti, and success.
items.katha: Devi promised to protect those remembering her regularly on Ashtami.
items.morning: Snan; Durga image; sankalpa.
items.daytime: Fruit or one‑meal fast; recite “Ya Devi Sarvabhuteshu” and short Saptashati portion.
items.mainpuja: Evening Durga puja with kumkum, flowers, kheer/fruit; aarti.
items.fastingrules: Fast ends after puja with prasad and food.
items.daan: Food, fruits, clothes to girls/women.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ दुं दुर्गायै नमः” 108.

items.hindiname: वैकुण्ठ एकादशी / मोक्षदा एकादशी / गीता जयंती
items.muhurat: Sunrise–next sunrise; Gita path during day drikpanchang+2
items.significance: Most important Ekadashi in many Vaishnava temples; gates of Vaikuntha symbolically open; also Mokshada Ekadashi and Gita Jayanti (Kurukshetra day).
items.katha: Story of a king whose father suffered in hell; by observing Mokshada Ekadashi and donating its punya, he saved him; Gita spoken on this day.
items.morning: Early snan; Vishnu image; Ekadashi sankalpa; place Gita near altar.
items.daytime: No grains; fruits/milk; read at least one chapter or selected verses of Gita; Mokshada katha.
items.mainpuja: Evening Vaikuntha Narayana puja; aarti; in temples, special Vaikuntha Dwara darshan.
items.fastingrules: Dwadashi Parana with tulsi‑water and light food; keep mind on moksha‑sankalpa.
items.daan: Food, books (Gita), clothes; support to Gita teaching projects.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108/1008; plus reading Gita verses.

items.significance: Evening fast for forgiveness, health, prosperity in bright fortnight.
items.katha: Pradosh legends: Shiva’s Tandava at this time removes devotees’ sins and sorrows.
items.morning: Morning snan; Shiva sthapana; sankalpa.
items.daytime: Fruits/milk fast; “Om Namah Shivaya” japa.
items.mainpuja: Pradosh abhishek, bilva‑puja, incense, lamp; Mahamrityunjaya japa; aarti.
items.fastingrules: Fast ends after puja with satvik meal.
items.daan: Milk, rice, sweets; bel leaves, oil lamps to temple.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” & “ॐ त्र्यम्बकं यजामहे…” 108 each.

items.muhurat: Snan‑daan morning; Dattatreya puja any time; night satsang drikpanchang+1
items.significance: Full Moon considered climax of Margashirsha month; Dattatreya Jayanti for seekers of wisdom, avadhuta‑marg, and guru‑kripa.
items.katha: Dattatreya, son of Atri–Anasuya, is guru of gurus, embodiment of Trinity; his life teaches learning from all of nature.
items.morning: Early snan (river if possible); set Dattatreya or simple trinity symbol; Purnima vrat sankalpa.
items.daytime: Partial fast or one‑meal; read Dattatreya Upanishad stories or Avadhuta Gita excerpts; japa.
items.mainpuja: Evening satsang or bhajan; Dattatreya puja with incense, flowers; aarti; moon‑darshan.
items.fastingrules: Fast broken after night puja or next morning with satvik food.
items.daan: Food, clothes, blankets; support to sadhus, gurukuls.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ द्रां दत्तात्रेयाय नमः” 108/1008 times.

items.tithimonth: Pausha Krishna Chaturthi (North) / Margashirsha Shukla Chaturthi (alt)
items.significance: Monthly Ganesha fast for removing obstacles and giving success near year‑end.
items.katha: Generic Sankashti katha: struggling devotees rescued from misfortune by this vrat and Ganesha’s grace.
items.morning: Pre‑dawn snan; Ganesha sthapana; fast sankalpa.
items.daytime: Nirjal/fruit fast; “Om Gam Ganapataye Namah” japa; Atharvashirsha recitation.
items.mainpuja: Evening puja, abhishek, durva, modak; katha; aarti; Moon darshan and arghya.
items.fastingrules: Fast ends only after Moon sight and offering; then prasad and light meal.
items.daan: Modak, laddoo, stationery for children, donations for students.
items.notes: Mantra: “ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108/1008 times.

items.englishname: (No major national festival; year‑end sadhana focus)
items.significance: Good day to review year’s sadhana, renew sankalpa for next year, and do gratitude japa.
items.katha: Not scripturally fixed, but widely used for introspection and planning with dharmic focus.
items.morning: Morning snan; short puja to Ishta Devata.
items.daytime: List key learnings, vrats done, plans for coming year’s festivals and seva.
items.mainpuja: Evening deepa, japa, and sankalpa writing.
items.fastingrules: No fast required; keep food satvik and modest.
items.daan: Food, coins to poor; resolve for planned, systematic daan next year.
items.notes: Mantra: choose your ishta‑mantra (e.g. “ॐ नमः शिवाय” / “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय”) 108+ with gratitude bhava.
